Authors:
Hong Ma, Ji Qi, Chien-Hsun Huang, Caifei Zhang, Yi Hu, Jing
Guo, Xinping Qi, Zhongyang Li
Title:
Fern nuclear phylogeny and phylogenomics support ancient WGD
events and expansion of numerous transcription factor families
Keywords:
fferns phylogeny, nuclear genes, transcriptomes,
divergence time estimation, whole-genome duplication, transcription
factors
Abstract:
Ferns form a sister lineage to seed plants, with both
ancient lineages and recently divergent species. Ferns have
exceptionally high chromosome numbers and are thought to have
experienced whole-genome duplications (WGDs). However, WGDs have not
been investigated molecularly across the expanse of fern diversity and
how regulatory gene families have evolved is unclear. To address these
questions, we generated transcriptomes from 125 ferns and 2 lycophytes,
with three public datasets, to represent all 14 fern orders (85% of
families) and all three lycophyte orders. Nuclear genes were selected to
reconstruct a strongly supported fern phylogeny, with monophyly of and
relationships among all four subclasses and nearly all orders and
families. On the other hand, in Glecheniales, one family (Dipteridaceae)
is sister to a clade combining another family (Gleicheniaceae) and the
order Hymenophyllales, In addition, new phylogenetic relationships for
suborders and families in Polypodiales are strongly supported. Molecular
clock analysis estimated that the ancestors of ferns and seed plants
separated in early Devonian at ~400 Mya, with gradual divergences of
orders from ~370 to 200 Mya. Strong evidence for multiple WGDs in the
fern evolutionary history was detected. Furthermore, analyses of
transcription factor families indicate that the vast majority of seed
plant families were present in the common ancestor of extent vascular
plants and parallel expansions of key regulators occurred in both ferns
and seed plants. This study provides a nuclear phylogenetic framework
and molecular evolutionary foundation for understanding gene function
evolution in ferns.
